comments.commentBody: #2:  It is too early to know whether there will be any Western teams next season.  And the fact that attendance at post-WWC matches roughly doubled, compared to pre-WWC attendance, to the point that at least a few teams may have turned a profit for the last part of the season (assuming that 5,000 is a breakeven point), flatly contradicts your claim that the result of the WWC championship match was that important.  The league's star players will be kept in the public eye through next summer's Olympics.  The real crunch will come in 2013-14, when there will be no WWC/Olympic angle.
I love Francesca, but the real key to her victory was her opponent choked.

Like everything else in golf, use of the belly putter involves a tradeoff. Your wrists are immobilized, so there is no tendency to yip...but you lose feel. The longer the shaft, the more awkward.
I would expect that, as belly- and long (over 47") putter proliferate, the heads will evolve into different shapes and sizes.
And the moment for making them illegal passed decades ago.

Rather than banish belly putters, after all a roll of the ball is a roll of the ball, can't we create and use standard balls that can't be hit more than, say, 280 hards off the tee?

The pros make a mockery of most courses, and it is now routine for par 4s to be over 500 yards.

Let's stop the distance madness!

Some parts of lessons are better learned with a keyboard and computer screen, and some are just not.

Computers will never be able to read expressions on faces, hear nuances in the voices of the question which allow more precise explanations addressed to the exact misunderstanding.

Great teachers will always be more valuable than electronic systems. But the guys in charge will still pay more for the equipment than for the gals' salaries.

FDRriseagain - Excuse me but finding personal property left behind in a bar is not stealing. There are many explanations why someone would not turn over a lost cellphone to the bartender, waitress, or beefy-man at the door. The man who found the first iPhone attempted to return it to Apple in more than one phone call but was given the cold shoulder. Only then did he contact Gizmodo.

Those men should never have been charged with a crime.

The fault rests with the employee who lost the iPhone and Apple's corporate culture of secrecy and superiority.

I just looked at the Crossword Puzzle Archive section on http://www.nytimes.com/pages/crosswords/index.html

How long has the ninth month been spelled as "Sepember"?
This is not the first recent Sunday puzzle that relied on phonetics  rather than orthography (colloquially typing) for its puns. I'm not liking this tendency.
Many thanks to all for the recovery good wishes!
The writer of dog fiction was Jack London.

Also I had meant to mention that the unique nature of this puzzle leads one to make so many wrong turns.
At first I had Florida coast neighbor. CUBA? No, it's five letters..
So maybe it's CUBAN?
Quite some time later, I finally realized that it was "Ivory Coast neighbor", and therefore GHANA.

Why don't they give the answers to all of the Second Sunday puzzles any more?  The answers to the acrostics are available, but I can't find the answers to the others anywhere. And I'm with you, Lois: I can't figure out the noted writer of fiction about dogs.  Thought it might be the Marley and Me author, but it doesn't fit.

Dr. W @ 40 - Actually I am quite shocked at your question since you were mentioned in the original post about WORDY.

After a couple of late comments on August 3 by yours truly, 5:30am commented as follows:

I'm giving a WORDY (new crossword academy trophy) to John for making me laugh, laugh, laugh at 78 and 85.

I'm sure they'll have coffee, Dr W, but you could email Brian to be sure (click on that link over there ---------------------->>>>>> to Lollapuzzoola).

About two weeks later I awarded my WORDY to Suejean for winning a contest and Suejean in turn later awarded it to WHH for figuring out that my repeated references to Carmen Santiago was the absent Karma Sartre. Now KS has it and we all await what he will do with it after he has polished it for the umpteenth time..

Of course, since the WORDY was 5:30am's crreation she can always give out another anytime.

I think I'd have a better chance at stopping a Bobby Hull slap shot, tackling Jim Brown in the open field, or hitting a homer off Nolan Ryan than solving this brain bending piece submitted by our DC (designated columnist) Tom Gaffney. Way out of my league but it was fun to toy with. Mother Teresa's home town heads a lengthy list of unknowns for me. Maybe the Sunday puzzle will be a little more user friendly.

5:30am- Glad to see you back blogside. Irene spared most on the coast but took out her wrath on those inland. She was a fickle little devil, huh? HBD.

I had never heard of Dana Delany before (since I don't get around much in celebrity land), but I certainly enjoyed the puzzle. It's not clear how they shared they work of constructing it, and I WONDER who came up with the idea.

I also enjoyed the Saturday puzzle, but didn't have time to write any comments about it. We had a new computer system installed at the library, and that kept us pretty busy.

Loved this puzzle, in spite of the fact that it took me 50% longer than usual to solve. I had trouble getting past the entries that didn't literally add IC to common expressions but instead used "sounds like" expressions. Last to fall was GAELICWARNING; first was KINGLYRIC. I thought all of the theme answers were very clever.

FANTASTIC NEWS!!! WE HAVE POWER! AND PHONE! AND CABLE! The laundry is underway, and the dishwasher is ready. This was 7 long days and 6 long nights, let me tell you! It will be interesting to read the statistics of how many trees had to be removed, poles replaced, etc.

Thanks for doing such a good job, Thomas Gaffney, a seamless transition.

LONG I for "End of July by the sound" is priceless; maybe the best clue of the year. It's wordplay times 3 (at least), since the long I sound is the ending sound in the word July, and because LONG I is a common map abbreviation for a place near New York City which has its own eponymous Sound, where you might like to visit at the end of July (though certainly not the end of August when a hurricane is coming, or late December, when a blizzard might blow through.)

One carp, though. I don't think RA's are even remotely dorm police. RA's are fellow students who are paid or otherwise compensated to counsel, advise, settle problems, infuse students with esprit de corps, etc. The campus police department is, well, the dorm police.
I don't get the play on words in the clue "married couple." Help!
I'm afraid I don't get ARS for "Married Couple?" What am I missing?
Ah: two r's in "marriage."

Mark Twain, on the "Arab Spring" and other revolutions:

There is a phrase which has grown so common in the world's mouth that it has come to seem to have sense and meaning—the sense and meaning implied when it is used; that is the phrase which refers to this or that or the other nation as possibly being "capable of self-government"; and the implied sense of it is, that there has been a nation somewhere, some time or other which wasn't capable of it—wasn't as able to govern itself as some self-appointed specialists were or would be to govern it. The master minds of all nations, in all ages, have sprung in affluent multitude from the mass of the nation, and from the mass of the nation only—not from its privileged classes; and so, no matter what the nation's intellectual grade was; whether high or low, the bulk of its ability was in the long ranks of its nameless and its poor, and so it never saw the day that it had not the material in abundance whereby to govern itself. Which is to assert an always self-proven fact: that even the best governed and most free and most enlightened monarchy is still behind the best condition attainable by its people; and that the same is true of kindred governments of lower grades, all the way down to the lowest.

A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court (1889) ch. 25
IT is amazing STORY from amazing journalist .Now the west has changed by sporting revolt .

I think #2's got it. Voters are economically rational. Regarding taxes, deficits and the future taxes they imply, voters are more affected by the national economy than the state economy. That is because federal taxes are higher than state taxes and often more progressive and therefore more responsive to economic fluctuations. Also, national economy news is multiplied by the media, but state economic news is hard to find.

I can't speak to what the IB has become today, but it was orginally designed and implemented at the Ecole Internationale de Geneve and the United Nations International School (in NYC) as a single program of study and examinations which would allow students in international schools to meet the requirements to attend university in their home countries; prior to its creation, students had to prepare for specific sets of national exams such as the French Baccalaureat, the British GCE, the Swiss Maturité, the German Abitur, the Italian Maturita, and so forth...  As in the rest of life, your mileage may vary...
